description: Origin uncertain; possibly from Middle Dutch or Middle Low German brake (“nose ring, curb, flax brake”), which according to Watkins is related to sense 4 and from Proto-Germanic *brekaną (“to break”).

definitionGroups.group: A device used to slow or stop the motion of a wheel, or of a vehicle, usually by friction (although other resistive forces, such as electromagnetic fields or aerodynamic drag, can also be used); also, the controls or apparatus used to engage such a mechanism such as the pedal in a car. [from 18th c.]

entries.meaning: The act of braking, of using a brake to slow down a machine or vehicle
examples: give the car a quick brake

entries.meaning: (engineering) An apparatus for testing the power of a steam engine or other motor by weighing the amount of friction that the motor will overcome; a friction brake.
(figuratively) Something used to retard or stop some action, process etc.

definitionGroups.group: (military) An ancient engine of war analogous to the crossbow and ballista.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The winch of a crossbow. [14th–19th c.]
(chiefly nautical) The handle of a pump.
A baker's kneading trough.

definitionGroups.group: A device used to confine or prevent the motion of an animal.

entries.meaning: A frame for confining a refractory horse while the smith is shoeing him.
An enclosure to restrain cattle, horses, etc.
examples: He was shooting, and the field where the [cock-fighting] ring was verged on the shooting-brake where the rabbits were.

entries.meaning: A cart or carriage without a body, used in breaking in horses.W
A carriage for transporting shooting parties and their equipment.W
That part of a carriage, as of a movable battery, or engine, which enables it to turn.

verbs.description: brake (third-person singular simple present brakes, present participle braking, simple past and past participle braked)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To operate (a) brake(s).
(intransitive) To be stopped or slowed (as if) by braking.

description: Apparently a shortened form of bracken. (Compare chick, chicken.)

entries.meaning: A fern; bracken (Pteridium). [from 14th c.]
Any fern in the genus Pteris

description: From Old English bracu, first attested in plural form fearnbraca (“thickets of fern”), probably from Proto-Germanic *brekaną (“to break”) and influenced by sense 2 (“fern”). Compare Middle Low German brake (“stump, branch”).

entries.meaning: A thicket, or an area overgrown with briers etc. [from 15th c.]
examples: He halts, and searches with his eyes
And now at distance can discern
A stirring in a brake of fern  […]

description: Late Middle English, from Middle Low German brake, Dutch braak, Old Dutch braeke; possibly related to sense 1.

entries.meaning: A tool used for breaking flax or hemp. [from 15th c.]
A type of machine for bending sheet metal. (See wikipedia.)
A large, heavy harrow for breaking clods after ploughing; a drag.

verbs.description: brake (third-person singular simple present brakes, present participle braking, simple past and past participle braked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bruise and crush; to knead
examples: The farmer's son brakes the flax while mother brakes the bread dough

entries.meaning: (transitive) To pulverise with a harrow
(obsolete) A cage. [16th–17th c.]
(now historical) A type of torture instrument. [from 16th c.]
examples: Methods of applying pain were many and ingenious, in particular the ways of twisting, stretching and manipulating the body out of shape, normally falling under the catch-all term of the rack, or the brakes.

entries.meaning: (archaic) simple past tense of break
